instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Trackpad no Keyboard
threads.message:
Hello, hope you guys are great.

I am very new to this so bear with me please. 

I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with no trackpad and no keyboard. I measured power on  J4813 (keyboard connector):

1.  <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H_TPAD</SIGNAL> is 3.4
2.  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_TPAD</SIGNAL> is 2.8v all across the rail. 

<CHIP>U4801</CHIP> doesnt seem to be corroded or damaged. Im trying to figure out where is <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> created. I belive in  <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> ?

<CHIP>U1900</CHIP> doesnt seem damaged also. But its measuring 1.1v on pin 14.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Trackpad no Keyboard
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

As page 81 shows, <SIGNAL>3V3_S4_TPAD</SIGNAL> comes from <SIGNAL>3V3_S4_FET</SIGNAL> (<TRANSISTOR>Q8000</TRANSISTOR>).
Post <TRANSISTOR>Q8000</TRANSISTOR>/2 voltages.
Check diode mode on <SIGNAL>3V3_S4_TPAD</SIGNAL> w/ and w/ trackpad connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Trackpad no Keyboard
threads.message:
Thank you for your welcome.

From <TRANSISTOR>Q8000</TRANSISTOR> i get 2.8v from pp3v3 s4 and 3.3 from pp3v3 s5

Diode mode  <SIGNAL>3V3_S4_TPAD</SIGNAL> on pin 20 of J4813

w/o trackpad connected: 0.139v

w/trackpad connected: 0.139v

whats the purpose of the diode mode measurement in this case? 

Thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Trackpad no Keyboard
threads.message:
Looks like no short, so probably bad <TRANSISTOR>Q8000</TRANSISTOR>, or incorrectly controlled.

I asked you to post voltages for two transistors, not two pins of one transistor...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Trackpad no Keyboard
threads.message:
Yes, sorry. Can it be any of the <TRANSISTOR>Q8000</TRANSISTOR>'s?

1. <TRANSISTOR>Q8000</TRANSISTOR> = 

Source 3.3v - Gate 3.25v - Drain 2.8v

1. <TRANSISTOR>Q8050</TRANSISTOR> =

Source 5.0v - Gate 0.0v  - Drain 5.0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Trackpad no Keyboard
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Trackpad no Keyboard
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Trackpad no Keyboard
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q8002</TRANSISTOR> is dual MOSFET, did you check at pins 1, 2, 6???

Change <TRANSISTOR>Q8000</TRANSISTOR>, just in case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Trackpad no Keyboard
threads.message: Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q8000</TRANSISTOR> and now we have keyboard and trackpad. Thanks a lot for your patience and guidance.
